Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 7, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Imagine that one day,
you're summoned before a government panel. Even though you haven't 
committed any crime, or been formally charged with one, you are repeatedly questioned
about your political views, accused of disloyalty, and asked to incriminate your friends
and associates. If you don't cooperate,
you risk jail or losing your job. This is exactly what happened in
the United States in the 1950s as part of a campaign to expose
suspected communists. Named after its most 
notorious practitioner, the phenomenon known as McCarthyism
destroyed thousands of lives and careers. For over a decade, American political 
leaders trampled democratic freedoms in the name of protecting them. During the 1930s and 1940s, there had been an active but small
communist party in the United States. Its record was mixed. While it played crucial roles in wider 
progressive struggles for labor and civil rights, it also supported the Soviet Union. From the start, the American 
Communist Party faced attacks from conservatives and business leaders, as well as from liberals who criticized
its ties to the oppressive Soviet regime. During World War II, when the USA
and USSR were allied against Hitler, some American communists actually
spied for the Russians. When the Cold War escalated
and this espionage became known, domestic communism came to be seen
as a threat to national security. But the attempt to eliminate that threat soon turned into the longest lasting
and most widespread episode of political repression 
in American history. Spurred on by a network of bureaucrats, politicians, journalists, and businessmen, the campaign wildly exaggerated
the danger of communist subversion. The people behind it harassed anyone suspected of holding 
left-of-center political views or associating with those who did. If you hung modern art on your walls, had a multiracial social circle, or signed petitions against
nuclear weapons, you might just have been a communist. Starting in the late 1940s, FBI Director J. Edgar Hoover used the resources of his agency
to hunt down such supposed communists and eliminate them from any
position of influence within American society. And the narrow criteria that Hoover
and his allies used to screen federal employees spread to the rest of the country. Soon, Hollywood studios, universities, car manufacturers, and thousands of other public
and private employers were imposing the same political tests
on the men and women who worked for them. Meanwhile, Congress conducted 
its own witchhunt subpoenaing hundreds of people
to testify before investigative bodies like the House Un-American 
Activities Committee. If they refused to cooperate,
they could be jailed for contempt, or more commonly, fired and blacklisted. Ambitious politicians, like Richard Nixon and Joseph McCarthy, used such hearings as a partisan weapon accusing democrats 
of being soft on communism and deliberately losing China
to the Communist Bloc. McCarthy, a Republican senator 
from Wisconsin became notorious by flaunting
ever-changing lists of alleged communists within the State Department. Egged on by other politicians, he continued to make 
outrageous accusations while distorting or fabricating evidence. Many citizens reviled McCarthy
while others praised him. And when the Korean War broke out,
McCarthy seemed vindicated. Once he became chair of the Senate's permanent subcommittee
on investigations in 1953, McCarthy recklessness increased. It was his investigation of the army that 
finally turned public opinion against him and diminished his power. McCarthy's colleagues 
in the Senate censured him and he died less than three years later,
probably from alcoholism. McCarthyism ended as well. It had ruined hundreds, 
if not thousands, of lives and drastically narrowed the American
political spectrum. Its damage to democratic institutions
would be long lasting. In all likelihood, there were both
Democrats and Republicans who knew that the anti-communist
purges were deeply unjust but feared that directly opposing them
would hurt their careers. Even the Supreme Court failed
to stop the witchhunt, condoning serious violations
of constitutional rights in the name of national security. Was domestic communism an actual
threat to the American government? Perhaps, though a small one. But the reaction to it was so extreme
that it caused far more damage than the threat itself. And if new demagogues appeared
in uncertain times to attack unpopular minorities
in the name of patriotism, could it all happen again?

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What was the goal of McCarthyism?
Options: A. Rescinding democratic freedoms of citizens, B. Destroying careers of politicians, C. Exposing suspected communists, D. Limiting governmental regulations
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the primary goal of the campaign known as McCarthyism in the United States during the 1950s? Options: A. To expose suspected fascists, B. To expose suspected communists, C. To promote labor and civil rights, D. To support the Soviet Union Correct Option: B
Question 2: Who was the FBI Director that used the resources of his agency to hunt down suspected communists in the late 1940s? Options: A. J. Edgar Hoover, B. Joseph McCarthy, C. Richard Nixon, D. Harry Truman Correct Option: A
Question 3: What was the consequence for individuals who refused to cooperate with the House Un-American Activities Committee? Options: A. They were awarded for their bravery, B. They were jailed for contempt or fired and blacklisted, C. They were promoted in their careers, D. They were ignored by the public Correct Option: B
Question 4: What was the result of the campaign's attempt to eliminate the perceived threat of communism in the United States? Options: A. It led to a significant increase in communist party membership, B. It resulted in the longest lasting and most widespread episode of political repression in American history, C. It had no impact on American society, D. It led to a decrease in the number of people suspected of holding left-of-center views Correct Option: B
Question 5: How did the narrow criteria used by J. Edgar Hoover and his allies to screen federal employees affect the rest of the country? Options: A. It had no impact on the private sector, B. It led to a more diverse and inclusive workforce, C. It resulted in the same political tests being imposed on employees in the public and private sectors, D. It led to a decrease in the number of people employed by the federal government Correct Option: C
Question 6: What was the outcome of Joseph McCarthy's investigation of the army? Options: A. It led to the discovery of a large number of communists within the army, B. It resulted in the censure of McCarthy by his Senate colleagues and a decline in his power, C. It had no impact on McCarthy's career, D. It led to McCarthy's promotion to a higher position in the Senate Correct Option: B
Question 7: What was the long-term impact of McCarthyism on American democratic institutions? Options: A. It resulted in a more robust and resilient democracy, B. It had no lasting impact on American democratic institutions, C. It caused significant and long-lasting damage to democratic institutions, D. It led to a decrease in the number of people participating in the democratic process Correct Option: C
Question 8: What factors contributed to the extreme reaction to domestic communism in the United States? Options: A. The small size of the communist party and its lack of influence, B. The ties of the American Communist Party to the Soviet Union and the espionage activities of some American communists during World War II, C. The lack of a perceived threat to national security, D. The absence of a network of bureaucrats, politicians, journalists, and businessmen supporting the campaign Correct Option: B
Question 9: What could happen if new demagogues appeared in uncertain times to attack unpopular minorities in the name of patriotism? Options: A. It could lead to a more inclusive and tolerant society, B. It could result in a repeat of the McCarthyism episode, C. It would have no impact on American society, D. It would lead to a decline in the number of people participating in the democratic process Correct Option: B
Question 10: What was the relationship between the reaction to domestic communism and the actual threat posed by it? Options: A. The reaction was proportionate to the threat, B. The reaction was extreme and caused more damage than the threat itself, C. The reaction had no impact on the lives of individuals suspected of holding left-of-center views, D. The threat was greater than the reaction Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 1. 

This question has the same intent as the ground truth MCQ, which is to identify the primary goal of McCarthyism. The options provided in Question 1 are also similar to those in the ground truth MCQ, with the correct option being "to expose suspected communists." The content of Question 1 aligns with the information provided in the transcript, which describes McCarthyism as a campaign to expose suspected communists in the United States during the 1950s.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 1.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 7, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Imagine that one day,
you're summoned before a government panel. Even though you haven't 
committed any crime, or been formally charged with one, you are repeatedly questioned
about your political views, accused of disloyalty, and asked to incriminate your friends
and associates. If you don't cooperate,
you risk jail or losing your job. This is exactly what happened in
the United States in the 1950s as part of a campaign to expose
suspected communists. Named after its most 
notorious practitioner, the phenomenon known as McCarthyism
destroyed thousands of lives and careers. For over a decade, American political 
leaders trampled democratic freedoms in the name of protecting them. During the 1930s and 1940s, there had been an active but small
communist party in the United States. Its record was mixed. While it played crucial roles in wider 
progressive struggles for labor and civil rights, it also supported the Soviet Union. From the start, the American 
Communist Party faced attacks from conservatives and business leaders, as well as from liberals who criticized
its ties to the oppressive Soviet regime. During World War II, when the USA
and USSR were allied against Hitler, some American communists actually
spied for the Russians. When the Cold War escalated
and this espionage became known, domestic communism came to be seen
as a threat to national security. But the attempt to eliminate that threat soon turned into the longest lasting
and most widespread episode of political repression 
in American history. Spurred on by a network of bureaucrats, politicians, journalists, and businessmen, the campaign wildly exaggerated
the danger of communist subversion. The people behind it harassed anyone suspected of holding 
left-of-center political views or associating with those who did. If you hung modern art on your walls, had a multiracial social circle, or signed petitions against
nuclear weapons, you might just have been a communist. Starting in the late 1940s, FBI Director J. Edgar Hoover used the resources of his agency
to hunt down such supposed communists and eliminate them from any
position of influence within American society. And the narrow criteria that Hoover
and his allies used to screen federal employees spread to the rest of the country. Soon, Hollywood studios, universities, car manufacturers, and thousands of other public
and private employers were imposing the same political tests
on the men and women who worked for them. Meanwhile, Congress conducted 
its own witchhunt subpoenaing hundreds of people
to testify before investigative bodies like the House Un-American 
Activities Committee. If they refused to cooperate,
they could be jailed for contempt, or more commonly, fired and blacklisted. Ambitious politicians, like Richard Nixon and Joseph McCarthy, used such hearings as a partisan weapon accusing democrats 
of being soft on communism and deliberately losing China
to the Communist Bloc. McCarthy, a Republican senator 
from Wisconsin became notorious by flaunting
ever-changing lists of alleged communists within the State Department. Egged on by other politicians, he continued to make 
outrageous accusations while distorting or fabricating evidence. Many citizens reviled McCarthy
while others praised him. And when the Korean War broke out,
McCarthy seemed vindicated. Once he became chair of the Senate's permanent subcommittee
on investigations in 1953, McCarthy recklessness increased. It was his investigation of the army that 
finally turned public opinion against him and diminished his power. McCarthy's colleagues 
in the Senate censured him and he died less than three years later,
probably from alcoholism. McCarthyism ended as well. It had ruined hundreds, 
if not thousands, of lives and drastically narrowed the American
political spectrum. Its damage to democratic institutions
would be long lasting. In all likelihood, there were both
Democrats and Republicans who knew that the anti-communist
purges were deeply unjust but feared that directly opposing them
would hurt their careers. Even the Supreme Court failed
to stop the witchhunt, condoning serious violations
of constitutional rights in the name of national security. Was domestic communism an actual
threat to the American government? Perhaps, though a small one. But the reaction to it was so extreme
that it caused far more damage than the threat itself. And if new demagogues appeared
in uncertain times to attack unpopular minorities
in the name of patriotism, could it all happen again?

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How long did the era of McCarthyism last?
Options: A. One year, B. Twenty-five years, C. Over a decade, D. It never ended, it continues still today
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the primary goal of the campaign known as McCarthyism in the United States during the 1950s? Options: A. To expose suspected fascists, B. To expose suspected communists, C. To promote labor and civil rights, D. To support the Soviet Union Correct Option: B
Question 2: Who was the FBI Director that used the resources of his agency to hunt down suspected communists in the late 1940s? Options: A. J. Edgar Hoover, B. Joseph McCarthy, C. Richard Nixon, D. Harry Truman Correct Option: A
Question 3: What was the consequence for individuals who refused to cooperate with the House Un-American Activities Committee? Options: A. They were awarded for their bravery, B. They were jailed for contempt or fired and blacklisted, C. They were promoted in their careers, D. They were ignored by the public Correct Option: B
Question 4: What was the result of the campaign's attempt to eliminate the perceived threat of communism in the United States? Options: A. It led to a significant increase in communist party membership, B. It resulted in the longest lasting and most widespread episode of political repression in American history, C. It had no impact on American society, D. It led to a decrease in the number of people suspected of holding left-of-center views Correct Option: B
Question 5: How did the narrow criteria used by J. Edgar Hoover and his allies to screen federal employees affect the rest of the country? Options: A. It had no impact on the private sector, B. It led to a more diverse and inclusive workforce, C. It resulted in the same political tests being imposed on employees in the public and private sectors, D. It led to a decrease in the number of people employed by the federal government Correct Option: C
Question 6: What was the outcome of Joseph McCarthy's investigation of the army? Options: A. It led to the discovery of a large number of communists within the army, B. It resulted in the censure of McCarthy by his Senate colleagues and a decline in his power, C. It had no impact on McCarthy's career, D. It led to McCarthy's promotion to a higher position in the Senate Correct Option: B
Question 7: What was the long-term impact of McCarthyism on American democratic institutions? Options: A. It resulted in a more robust and resilient democracy, B. It had no lasting impact on American democratic institutions, C. It caused significant and long-lasting damage to democratic institutions, D. It led to a decrease in the number of people participating in the democratic process Correct Option: C
Question 8: What factors contributed to the extreme reaction to domestic communism in the United States? Options: A. The small size of the communist party and its lack of influence, B. The ties of the American Communist Party to the Soviet Union and the espionage activities of some American communists during World War II, C. The lack of a perceived threat to national security, D. The absence of a network of bureaucrats, politicians, journalists, and businessmen supporting the campaign Correct Option: B
Question 9: What could happen if new demagogues appeared in uncertain times to attack unpopular minorities in the name of patriotism? Options: A. It could lead to a more inclusive and tolerant society, B. It could result in a repeat of the McCarthyism episode, C. It would have no impact on American society, D. It would lead to a decline in the number of people participating in the democratic process Correct Option: B
Question 10: What was the relationship between the reaction to domestic communism and the actual threat posed by it? Options: A. The reaction was proportionate to the threat, B. The reaction was extreme and caused more damage than the threat itself, C. The reaction had no impact on the lives of individuals suspected of holding left-of-center views, D. The threat was greater than the reaction Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that the most similar generated MCQ is not an exact match, but Question 4 is the closest in terms of question intent and content.

However, since Question 4 does not ask about the duration of McCarthyism, I re-examined the generated MCQs and found that none of them directly ask about the duration of McCarthyism.

But, I can suggest that the closest match would be a question that provides information about the duration of McCarthyism in its options or content. Unfortunately, none of the generated MCQs provide a direct match.

If I had to choose a generated MCQ that might be related to the duration of McCarthyism, I would choose Question 7, which talks about the long-term impact of McCarthyism on American democratic institutions. However, this is a weak match, as it does not directly ask about the duration of McCarthyism.

Therefore, I must conclude that there is no generated MCQ that closely matches the ground truth MCQ.

If I had to provide an index, I would say that the closest match is not available, but if I had to choose a weak match, it would be Question 7.

about your political views, accused of disloyalty, and asked to incriminate your friends
and associates. If you don't cooperate,

the United States in the 1950s as part of a campaign to expose
suspected communists. Named after its most

and this espionage became known, domestic communism came to be seen

the danger of communist subversion. The people behind it harassed anyone suspected of holding

finally turned public opinion against him and diminished his power. McCarthy's colleagues

would be long lasting. In all likelihood, there were both

would hurt their careers. Even the Supreme Court failed
to stop the witchhunt, condoning serious violations

that it caused far more damage than the threat itself. And if new demagogues appeared
in uncertain times to attack unpopular minorities
in the name of patriotism, could it all happen again?

**Ground Truth MCQ**:

Options: A. Conservatives, B. Liberals, C. Business leaders, D. B and c only, E. All of the above
Correct Option: E

**Transcript**:
Imagine that one day,
you're summoned before a government panel. Even though you haven't 
committed any crime, or been formally charged with one, you are repeatedly questioned
about your political views, accused of disloyalty, and asked to incriminate your friends
and associates. If you don't cooperate,
you risk jail or losing your job. This is exactly what happened in
the United States in the 1950s as part of a campaign to expose
suspected communists. Named after its most 
notorious practitioner, the phenomenon known as McCarthyism
destroyed thousands of lives and careers. For over a decade, American political 
leaders trampled democratic freedoms in the name of protecting them. During the 1930s and 1940s, there had been an active but small
communist party in the United States. Its record was mixed. While it played crucial roles in wider 
progressive struggles for labor and civil rights, it also supported the Soviet Union. From the start, the American 
Communist Party faced attacks from conservatives and business leaders, as well as from liberals who criticized
its ties to the oppressive Soviet regime. During World War II, when the USA
and USSR were allied against Hitler, some American communists actually
spied for the Russians. When the Cold War escalated
and this espionage became known, domestic communism came to be seen
as a threat to national security. But the attempt to eliminate that threat soon turned into the longest lasting
and most widespread episode of political repression 
in American history. Spurred on by a network of bureaucrats, politicians, journalists, and businessmen, the campaign wildly exaggerated
the danger of communist subversion. The people behind it harassed anyone suspected of holding 
left-of-center political views or associating with those who did. If you hung modern art on your walls, had a multiracial social circle, or signed petitions against
nuclear weapons, you might just have been a communist. Starting in the late 1940s, FBI Director J. Edgar Hoover used the resources of his agency
to hunt down such supposed communists and eliminate them from any
position of influence within American society. And the narrow criteria that Hoover
and his allies used to screen federal employees spread to the rest of the country. Soon, Hollywood studios, universities, car manufacturers, and thousands of other public
and private employers were imposing the same political tests
on the men and women who worked for them. Meanwhile, Congress conducted 
its own witchhunt subpoenaing hundreds of people
to testify before investigative bodies like the House Un-American 
Activities Committee. If they refused to cooperate,
they could be jailed for contempt, or more commonly, fired and blacklisted. Ambitious politicians, like Richard Nixon and Joseph McCarthy, used such hearings as a partisan weapon accusing democrats 
of being soft on communism and deliberately losing China
to the Communist Bloc. McCarthy, a Republican senator 
from Wisconsin became notorious by flaunting
ever-changing lists of alleged communists within the State Department. Egged on by other politicians, he continued to make 
outrageous accusations while distorting or fabricating evidence. Many citizens reviled McCarthy
while others praised him. And when the Korean War broke out,
McCarthy seemed vindicated. Once he became chair of the Senate's permanent subcommittee
on investigations in 1953, McCarthy recklessness increased. It was his investigation of the army that 
finally turned public opinion against him and diminished his power. McCarthy's colleagues 
in the Senate censured him and he died less than three years later,
probably from alcoholism. McCarthyism ended as well. It had ruined hundreds, 
if not thousands, of lives and drastically narrowed the American
political spectrum. Its damage to democratic institutions
would be long lasting. In all likelihood, there were both
Democrats and Republicans who knew that the anti-communist
purges were deeply unjust but feared that directly opposing them
would hurt their careers. Even the Supreme Court failed
to stop the witchhunt, condoning serious violations
of constitutional rights in the name of national security. Was domestic communism an actual
threat to the American government? Perhaps, though a small one. But the reaction to it was so extreme
that it caused far more damage than the threat itself. And if new demagogues appeared
in uncertain times to attack unpopular minorities
in the name of patriotism, could it all happen again?

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which organization run by J. Edgar Hoover sought to hunt down and eliminate communists from any position of influence in society?

Correct Option: B

to stop the witchhunt, condoning serious violations
of constitutional rights in the name of national security. Was domestic communism an actual
threat to the American government? Perhaps, though a small one. But the reaction to it was so extreme
that it caused far more damage than the threat itself. And if new demagogues appeared
in uncertain times to attack unpopular minorities
in the name of patriotism, could it all happen again?

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Failure to testify before the House Un-American Activities Committee could have resulted in being:
Options: A. Blacklisted and fired, B. Jailed for contempt, C. Deported, D. A and b only, E. All of the above
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the primary goal of the campaign known as McCarthyism in the United States during the 1950s? Options: A. To expose suspected fascists, B. To expose suspected communists, C. To promote labor and civil rights, D. To support the Soviet Union Correct Option: B
Question 2: Who was the FBI Director that used the resources of his agency to hunt down suspected communists in the late 1940s? Options: A. J. Edgar Hoover, B. Joseph McCarthy, C. Richard Nixon, D. Harry Truman Correct Option: A
Question 3: What was the consequence for individuals who refused to cooperate with the House Un-American Activities Committee? Options: A. They were awarded for their bravery, B. They were jailed for contempt or fired and blacklisted, C. They were promoted in their careers, D. They were ignored by the public Correct Option: B
Question 4: What was the result of the campaign's attempt to eliminate the perceived threat of communism in the United States? Options: A. It led to a significant increase in communist party membership, B. It resulted in the longest lasting and most widespread episode of political repression in American history, C. It had no impact on American society, D. It led to a decrease in the number of people suspected of holding left-of-center views Correct Option: B
Question 5: How did the narrow criteria used by J. Edgar Hoover and his allies to screen federal employees affect the rest of the country? Options: A. It had no impact on the private sector, B. It led to a more diverse and inclusive workforce, C. It resulted in the same political tests being imposed on employees in the public and private sectors, D. It led to a decrease in the number of people employed by the federal government Correct Option: C
Question 6: What was the outcome of Joseph McCarthy's investigation of the army? Options: A. It led to the discovery of a large number of communists within the army, B. It resulted in the censure of McCarthy by his Senate colleagues and a decline in his power, C. It had no impact on McCarthy's career, D. It led to McCarthy's promotion to a higher position in the Senate Correct Option: B
Question 7: What was the long-term impact of McCarthyism on American democratic institutions? Options: A. It resulted in a more robust and resilient democracy, B. It had no lasting impact on American democratic institutions, C. It caused significant and long-lasting damage to democratic institutions, D. It led to a decrease in the number of people participating in the democratic process Correct Option: C
Question 8: What factors contributed to the extreme reaction to domestic communism in the United States? Options: A. The small size of the communist party and its lack of influence, B. The ties of the American Communist Party to the Soviet Union and the espionage activities of some American communists during World War II, C. The lack of a perceived threat to national security, D. The absence of a network of bureaucrats, politicians, journalists, and businessmen supporting the campaign Correct Option: B
Question 9: What could happen if new demagogues appeared in uncertain times to attack unpopular minorities in the name of patriotism? Options: A. It could lead to a more inclusive and tolerant society, B. It could result in a repeat of the McCarthyism episode, C. It would have no impact on American society, D. It would lead to a decline in the number of people participating in the democratic process Correct Option: B
Question 10: What was the relationship between the reaction to domestic communism and the actual threat posed by it? Options: A. The reaction was proportionate to the threat, B. The reaction was extreme and caused more damage than the threat itself, C. The reaction had no impact on the lives of individuals suspected of holding left-of-center views, D. The threat was greater than the reaction Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 8, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Dating back at least 
to the time of Socrates, some early societies decided
that certain disputes, such as whether a person committed
a particular crime, should be heard by a group of citizens. Several centuries later, trial by jury
was introduced to England, where it became a fundamental feature
of the legal system, checking the government 
and involving citizens in decision-making. Juries decided whether defendants
would be tried on crimes, determined whether the accused
defendants were guilty, and resolved monetary disputes. While the American colonies eventually
cast off England's rule, its legal tradition of the jury persisted. The United States Constitution 
instructed a grand jury to decide whether 
criminal cases proceeded, required a jury to try all crimes,
except impeachment, and provided for juries 
in civil cases as well. Yet, in the US today,
grand juries often are not convened, and juries decide less than 4%
of criminal cases and less than 1% of civil cases
filed in court. That's at the same time as jury systems
in other countries are growing. So what happened in the U.S.? Part of the story lies in how the Supreme
Court has interpreted the Constitution. It's permitted plea bargaining, which now occurs in almost 
every criminal case. The way it works is the prosecutor
presents the accused with a decision of whether 
to plead guilty. If they accept the plea, the case won't
go in front of a jury, but they'll receive 
a shorter prison sentence than they'd get if 
a jury did convict them. The risk of a much greater 
prison sentence after a trial can frighten even an innocent defendant
into taking a plea. Between the 19th century 
and the 21st century, the proportion of guilty pleas
has increased from around 20% to 90%, and the numbers continue to grow. The Supreme Court has permitted
the use of another procedure that interferes with the jury called summary judgement. Using summary judgement, judges can
decide that civil trials are unnecessary if the people who sue 
have insufficient evidence. This is intended only for cases
where no reasonable jury would disagree. That's a difficult thing 
to determine, yet usage of summary judgement
has stretched to the point where some would argue it's being abused. For instance, judges grant fully,
or in part, over 70% of employers' requests to dismiss employment 
discrimination cases. In other cases, both the person who sues
and the person who defends forgo their right to go to court, instead resolving their dispute through
a professional arbitrator. These are generally lawyers, professors,
or former judges. Arbitration can be a smart decision
by both parties to avoid the requirements 
of a trial in court, but it's often agreed to unwittingly
when people sign contracts like employment applications
and consumer agreements. That can become a problem. For example, some arbitrators 
may be biased towards the companies
that give them cases. These are just some of the ways
in which juries have disappeared. But could the disappearance of juries
be a good thing? Well, juries aren't perfect. They're costly, time-consuming, and may make errors. And they're not always necessary, like when people can simply agree
to settle their disputes. But juries have their advantages. When properly selected, jurors are more representative of
the general population and don't have the same incentives
as prosecutors, legislators, or judges seeking reelection or promotion. The founders of the United States trusted
in the wisdom of impartial groups of citizens to check the power of all three branches
of government. And the jury trial itself has given
ordinary citizens a central role in upholding
the social fabric. So will the jury system in the U.S.
survive into the future?

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Juries decide less than __ percent of civil cases and less than __ percent of criminal cases.
Options: A. 55 and 60, B. 80 and 40, C. 4 and 1, D. 1 and 4
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: In which country was trial by jury introduced several centuries after the time of Socrates? Options: A. Greece, B. England, C. United States, D. Rome Correct Option: B
Question 2: What is a significant factor contributing to the decline of jury trials in the United States, according to the transcript? Options: A. The Supreme Court has abolished jury trials, B. The Constitution no longer requires jury trials, C. The Supreme Court has permitted procedures like plea bargaining and summary judgement, D. Juries are too costly and time-consuming Correct Option: C
Question 3: According to the United States Constitution, what is the primary function of a grand jury? Options: A. To try all crimes, except impeachment, B. To decide whether criminal cases proceed, C. To resolve monetary disputes, D. To determine the guilt of defendants Correct Option: B
Question 4: How has the use of plea bargaining affected the number of jury trials in the United States? Options: A. It has increased the number of jury trials, B. It has decreased the number of jury trials, C. It has had no impact on the number of jury trials, D. It has only affected civil cases Correct Option: B
Question 5: What is a potential issue with arbitration as a means of resolving disputes? Options: A. Arbitrators may be biased towards the companies that give them cases, B. Arbitration is too costly and time-consuming, C. Arbitration is only used in employment discrimination cases, D. Arbitration is only used in civil cases Correct Option: A
Question 6: According to the transcript, what is an advantage of juries in the United States? Options: A. They are less costly and time-consuming than other methods of dispute resolution, B. They are more representative of the general population and don't have the same incentives as prosecutors, legislators, or judges, C. They are only necessary in cases where people cannot agree to settle their disputes, D. They are perfect and never make errors Correct Option: B
Question 7: How has the proportion of guilty pleas changed in the United States between the 19th century and the 21st century? Options: A. It has decreased from 90% to 20%, B. It has increased from 20% to 90%, C. It has remained the same, D. It has only changed in civil cases Correct Option: B
Question 8: According to the transcript, what is the intended purpose of summary judgement? Options: A. To decide all civil cases, B. To determine the guilt of defendants, C. To resolve monetary disputes, D. To dismiss cases where no reasonable jury would disagree Correct Option: D
Question 9: What is a potential consequence of the decline of jury trials in the United States? Options: A. The power of the government will be unchecked, B. The social fabric will be upheld by other means, C. The number of errors in dispute resolution will decrease, D. The cost and time required for dispute resolution will decrease Correct Option: A
Question 10: Why did the founders of the United States trust in the wisdom of impartial groups of citizens, according to the transcript? Options: A. Because they were less costly and time-consuming than other methods of dispute resolution, B. Because they were more representative of the general population and didn't have the same incentives as prosecutors, legislators, or judges, C. Because they were only necessary in cases where people could not agree to settle their disputes, D. Because they were perfect and never made errors Correct Option: B
Question 11: What role do juries play in the United States system of government, according to the transcript? Options: A. They advise the President on matters of law, B. They check the power of the executive branch only, C. They check the power of all three branches of government, D. They have no role in checking the power of the government Correct Option: C
Question 12: According to the transcript, what percentage of criminal cases are decided by juries in the United States today? Options: A. Less than 1%, B. Less than 4%, C. More than 50%, D. More than 90% Correct Option: B
Question 13: What is a potential problem with the use of summary judgement, according to the transcript? Options: A. Judges may grant summary judgement too infrequently, B. Judges may grant summary judgement too frequently, C. Summary judgement is only used in employment discrimination cases, D. Summary judgement is only used in civil cases Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 12. 

Although the ground truth MCQ asks about both civil and criminal cases, and Question 12 only asks about criminal cases, the content and intent of Question 12 are the most similar to the ground truth MCQ among the provided options. Question 12 is the only generated MCQ that directly addresses the percentage of cases decided by juries, which is the main focus of the ground truth MCQ.

However, it's worth noting that there isn't a perfect match among the generated MCQs for the ground truth MCQ, as none of them ask about both civil and criminal cases.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 8, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Dating back at least 
to the time of Socrates, some early societies decided
that certain disputes, such as whether a person committed
a particular crime, should be heard by a group of citizens. Several centuries later, trial by jury
was introduced to England, where it became a fundamental feature
of the legal system, checking the government 
and involving citizens in decision-making. Juries decided whether defendants
would be tried on crimes, determined whether the accused
defendants were guilty, and resolved monetary disputes. While the American colonies eventually
cast off England's rule, its legal tradition of the jury persisted. The United States Constitution 
instructed a grand jury to decide whether 
criminal cases proceeded, required a jury to try all crimes,
except impeachment, and provided for juries 
in civil cases as well. Yet, in the US today,
grand juries often are not convened, and juries decide less than 4%
of criminal cases and less than 1% of civil cases
filed in court. That's at the same time as jury systems
in other countries are growing. So what happened in the U.S.? Part of the story lies in how the Supreme
Court has interpreted the Constitution. It's permitted plea bargaining, which now occurs in almost 
every criminal case. The way it works is the prosecutor
presents the accused with a decision of whether 
to plead guilty. If they accept the plea, the case won't
go in front of a jury, but they'll receive 
a shorter prison sentence than they'd get if 
a jury did convict them. The risk of a much greater 
prison sentence after a trial can frighten even an innocent defendant
into taking a plea. Between the 19th century 
and the 21st century, the proportion of guilty pleas
has increased from around 20% to 90%, and the numbers continue to grow. The Supreme Court has permitted
the use of another procedure that interferes with the jury called summary judgement. Using summary judgement, judges can
decide that civil trials are unnecessary if the people who sue 
have insufficient evidence. This is intended only for cases
where no reasonable jury would disagree. That's a difficult thing 
to determine, yet usage of summary judgement
has stretched to the point where some would argue it's being abused. For instance, judges grant fully,
or in part, over 70% of employers' requests to dismiss employment 
discrimination cases. In other cases, both the person who sues
and the person who defends forgo their right to go to court, instead resolving their dispute through
a professional arbitrator. These are generally lawyers, professors,
or former judges. Arbitration can be a smart decision
by both parties to avoid the requirements 
of a trial in court, but it's often agreed to unwittingly
when people sign contracts like employment applications
and consumer agreements. That can become a problem. For example, some arbitrators 
may be biased towards the companies
that give them cases. These are just some of the ways
in which juries have disappeared. But could the disappearance of juries
be a good thing? Well, juries aren't perfect. They're costly, time-consuming, and may make errors. And they're not always necessary, like when people can simply agree
to settle their disputes. But juries have their advantages. When properly selected, jurors are more representative of
the general population and don't have the same incentives
as prosecutors, legislators, or judges seeking reelection or promotion. The founders of the United States trusted
in the wisdom of impartial groups of citizens to check the power of all three branches
of government. And the jury trial itself has given
ordinary citizens a central role in upholding
the social fabric. So will the jury system in the U.S.
survive into the future?

**Ground Truth MCQ**:

Options: A. 90, B. 4, C. 56, D. 10
Correct Option: A

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 8, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Dating back at least 
to the time of Socrates, some early societies decided
that certain disputes, such as whether a person committed
a particular crime, should be heard by a group of citizens. Several centuries later, trial by jury
was introduced to England, where it became a fundamental feature
of the legal system, checking the government 
and involving citizens in decision-making. Juries decided whether defendants
would be tried on crimes, determined whether the accused
defendants were guilty, and resolved monetary disputes. While the American colonies eventually
cast off England's rule, its legal tradition of the jury persisted. The United States Constitution 
instructed a grand jury to decide whether 
criminal cases proceeded, required a jury to try all crimes,
except impeachment, and provided for juries 
in civil cases as well. Yet, in the US today,
grand juries often are not convened, and juries decide less than 4%
of criminal cases and less than 1% of civil cases
filed in court. That's at the same time as jury systems
in other countries are growing. So what happened in the U.S.? Part of the story lies in how the Supreme
Court has interpreted the Constitution. It's permitted plea bargaining, which now occurs in almost 
every criminal case. The way it works is the prosecutor
presents the accused with a decision of whether 
to plead guilty. If they accept the plea, the case won't
go in front of a jury, but they'll receive 
a shorter prison sentence than they'd get if 
a jury did convict them. The risk of a much greater 
prison sentence after a trial can frighten even an innocent defendant
into taking a plea. Between the 19th century 
and the 21st century, the proportion of guilty pleas
has increased from around 20% to 90%, and the numbers continue to grow. The Supreme Court has permitted
the use of another procedure that interferes with the jury called summary judgement. Using summary judgement, judges can
decide that civil trials are unnecessary if the people who sue 
have insufficient evidence. This is intended only for cases
where no reasonable jury would disagree. That's a difficult thing 
to determine, yet usage of summary judgement
has stretched to the point where some would argue it's being abused. For instance, judges grant fully,
or in part, over 70% of employers' requests to dismiss employment 
discrimination cases. In other cases, both the person who sues
and the person who defends forgo their right to go to court, instead resolving their dispute through
a professional arbitrator. These are generally lawyers, professors,
or former judges. Arbitration can be a smart decision
by both parties to avoid the requirements 
of a trial in court, but it's often agreed to unwittingly
when people sign contracts like employment applications
and consumer agreements. That can become a problem. For example, some arbitrators 
may be biased towards the companies
that give them cases. These are just some of the ways
in which juries have disappeared. But could the disappearance of juries
be a good thing? Well, juries aren't perfect. They're costly, time-consuming, and may make errors. And they're not always necessary, like when people can simply agree
to settle their disputes. But juries have their advantages. When properly selected, jurors are more representative of
the general population and don't have the same incentives
as prosecutors, legislators, or judges seeking reelection or promotion. The founders of the United States trusted
in the wisdom of impartial groups of citizens to check the power of all three branches
of government. And the jury trial itself has given
ordinary citizens a central role in upholding
the social fabric. So will the jury system in the U.S.
survive into the future?

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: For what reason would a criminal defendant plead guilty in a plea bargaining arrangement with the prosecutor?
Options: A. They are innocent, B. The defendant is worried about going to prison for a long time if convicted by the jury, C. There is insufficient evidence to prove their guilt, D. They want to win a civil case
Correct Option: B

A closer match is not found in the generated MCQs as none of them specifically ask about the reason a defendant would plead guilty in a plea bargaining arrangement. However, among the given options, Question 4 is the closest match as it discusses the impact of plea bargaining on jury trials.

But if we consider the intent of the ground truth MCQ, a more relevant question would be one that asks about the reason behind a defendant's decision to plead guilty. In this case, we can consider Question 7, which talks about the increase in guilty pleas due to plea bargaining, but it still doesn't directly answer the ground truth MCQ.

However, it is essential to note that the actual reason for pleading guilty is mentioned in the transcript as "The risk of a much greater prison sentence after a trial can frighten even an innocent defendant into taking a plea." This is closely related to option B of the ground truth MCQ.

Considering the intent and the closest possible match, I would say that Question 4 is the closest, but with a clarification that none of the generated MCQs perfectly match the ground truth MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 8, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Dating back at least 
to the time of Socrates, some early societies decided
that certain disputes, such as whether a person committed
a particular crime, should be heard by a group of citizens. Several centuries later, trial by jury
was introduced to England, where it became a fundamental feature
of the legal system, checking the government 
and involving citizens in decision-making. Juries decided whether defendants
would be tried on crimes, determined whether the accused
defendants were guilty, and resolved monetary disputes. While the American colonies eventually
cast off England's rule, its legal tradition of the jury persisted. The United States Constitution 
instructed a grand jury to decide whether 
criminal cases proceeded, required a jury to try all crimes,
except impeachment, and provided for juries 
in civil cases as well. Yet, in the US today,
grand juries often are not convened, and juries decide less than 4%
of criminal cases and less than 1% of civil cases
filed in court. That's at the same time as jury systems
in other countries are growing. So what happened in the U.S.? Part of the story lies in how the Supreme
Court has interpreted the Constitution. It's permitted plea bargaining, which now occurs in almost 
every criminal case. The way it works is the prosecutor
presents the accused with a decision of whether 
to plead guilty. If they accept the plea, the case won't
go in front of a jury, but they'll receive 
a shorter prison sentence than they'd get if 
a jury did convict them. The risk of a much greater 
prison sentence after a trial can frighten even an innocent defendant
into taking a plea. Between the 19th century 
and the 21st century, the proportion of guilty pleas
has increased from around 20% to 90%, and the numbers continue to grow. The Supreme Court has permitted
the use of another procedure that interferes with the jury called summary judgement. Using summary judgement, judges can
decide that civil trials are unnecessary if the people who sue 
have insufficient evidence. This is intended only for cases
where no reasonable jury would disagree. That's a difficult thing 
to determine, yet usage of summary judgement
has stretched to the point where some would argue it's being abused. For instance, judges grant fully,
or in part, over 70% of employers' requests to dismiss employment 
discrimination cases. In other cases, both the person who sues
and the person who defends forgo their right to go to court, instead resolving their dispute through
a professional arbitrator. These are generally lawyers, professors,
or former judges. Arbitration can be a smart decision
by both parties to avoid the requirements 
of a trial in court, but it's often agreed to unwittingly
when people sign contracts like employment applications
and consumer agreements. That can become a problem. For example, some arbitrators 
may be biased towards the companies
that give them cases. These are just some of the ways
in which juries have disappeared. But could the disappearance of juries
be a good thing? Well, juries aren't perfect. They're costly, time-consuming, and may make errors. And they're not always necessary, like when people can simply agree
to settle their disputes. But juries have their advantages. When properly selected, jurors are more representative of
the general population and don't have the same incentives
as prosecutors, legislators, or judges seeking reelection or promotion. The founders of the United States trusted
in the wisdom of impartial groups of citizens to check the power of all three branches
of government. And the jury trial itself has given
ordinary citizens a central role in upholding
the social fabric. So will the jury system in the U.S.
survive into the future?

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The jury in the United States was based on the jury in _________.
Options: A. Russia, B. England, C. Germany, D. Canada
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: In which country was trial by jury introduced several centuries after the time of Socrates? Options: A. Greece, B. England, C. United States, D. Rome Correct Option: B
Question 2: What is a significant factor contributing to the decline of jury trials in the United States, according to the transcript? Options: A. The Supreme Court has abolished jury trials, B. The Constitution no longer requires jury trials, C. The Supreme Court has permitted procedures like plea bargaining and summary judgement, D. Juries are too costly and time-consuming Correct Option: C
Question 3: According to the United States Constitution, what is the primary function of a grand jury? Options: A. To try all crimes, except impeachment, B. To decide whether criminal cases proceed, C. To resolve monetary disputes, D. To determine the guilt of defendants Correct Option: B
Question 4: How has the use of plea bargaining affected the number of jury trials in the United States? Options: A. It has increased the number of jury trials, B. It has decreased the number of jury trials, C. It has had no impact on the number of jury trials, D. It has only affected civil cases Correct Option: B
Question 5: What is a potential issue with arbitration as a means of resolving disputes? Options: A. Arbitrators may be biased towards the companies that give them cases, B. Arbitration is too costly and time-consuming, C. Arbitration is only used in employment discrimination cases, D. Arbitration is only used in civil cases Correct Option: A
Question 6: According to the transcript, what is an advantage of juries in the United States? Options: A. They are less costly and time-consuming than other methods of dispute resolution, B. They are more representative of the general population and don't have the same incentives as prosecutors, legislators, or judges, C. They are only necessary in cases where people cannot agree to settle their disputes, D. They are perfect and never make errors Correct Option: B
Question 7: How has the proportion of guilty pleas changed in the United States between the 19th century and the 21st century? Options: A. It has decreased from 90% to 20%, B. It has increased from 20% to 90%, C. It has remained the same, D. It has only changed in civil cases Correct Option: B
Question 8: According to the transcript, what is the intended purpose of summary judgement? Options: A. To decide all civil cases, B. To determine the guilt of defendants, C. To resolve monetary disputes, D. To dismiss cases where no reasonable jury would disagree Correct Option: D
Question 9: What is a potential consequence of the decline of jury trials in the United States? Options: A. The power of the government will be unchecked, B. The social fabric will be upheld by other means, C. The number of errors in dispute resolution will decrease, D. The cost and time required for dispute resolution will decrease Correct Option: A
Question 10: Why did the founders of the United States trust in the wisdom of impartial groups of citizens, according to the transcript? Options: A. Because they were less costly and time-consuming than other methods of dispute resolution, B. Because they were more representative of the general population and didn't have the same incentives as prosecutors, legislators, or judges, C. Because they were only necessary in cases where people could not agree to settle their disputes, D. Because they were perfect and never made errors Correct Option: B
Question 11: What role do juries play in the United States system of government, according to the transcript? Options: A. They advise the President on matters of law, B. They check the power of the executive branch only, C. They check the power of all three branches of government, D. They have no role in checking the power of the government Correct Option: C
Question 12: According to the transcript, what percentage of criminal cases are decided by juries in the United States today? Options: A. Less than 1%, B. Less than 4%, C. More than 50%, D. More than 90% Correct Option: B
Question 13: What is a potential problem with the use of summary judgement, according to the transcript? Options: A. Judges may grant summary judgement too infrequently, B. Judges may grant summary judgement too frequently, C. Summary judgement is only used in employment discrimination cases, D. Summary judgement is only used in civil cases Correct Option: B

Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is:

**Question 1: In which country was trial by jury introduced several centuries after the time of Socrates? Options: A. Greece, B. England, C. United States, D. Rome Correct Option: B**

This question has the same intent and content as the ground truth MCQ, which asks about the origin of the jury system in the United States. Both questions point to England as the country where trial by jury was introduced, which later influenced the United States.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 8, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Dating back at least 
to the time of Socrates, some early societies decided
that certain disputes, such as whether a person committed
a particular crime, should be heard by a group of citizens. Several centuries later, trial by jury
was introduced to England, where it became a fundamental feature
of the legal system, checking the government 
and involving citizens in decision-making. Juries decided whether defendants
would be tried on crimes, determined whether the accused
defendants were guilty, and resolved monetary disputes. While the American colonies eventually
cast off England's rule, its legal tradition of the jury persisted. The United States Constitution 
instructed a grand jury to decide whether 
criminal cases proceeded, required a jury to try all crimes,
except impeachment, and provided for juries 
in civil cases as well. Yet, in the US today,
grand juries often are not convened, and juries decide less than 4%
of criminal cases and less than 1% of civil cases
filed in court. That's at the same time as jury systems
in other countries are growing. So what happened in the U.S.? Part of the story lies in how the Supreme
Court has interpreted the Constitution. It's permitted plea bargaining, which now occurs in almost 
every criminal case. The way it works is the prosecutor
presents the accused with a decision of whether 
to plead guilty. If they accept the plea, the case won't
go in front of a jury, but they'll receive 
a shorter prison sentence than they'd get if 
a jury did convict them. The risk of a much greater 
prison sentence after a trial can frighten even an innocent defendant
into taking a plea. Between the 19th century 
and the 21st century, the proportion of guilty pleas
has increased from around 20% to 90%, and the numbers continue to grow. The Supreme Court has permitted
the use of another procedure that interferes with the jury called summary judgement. Using summary judgement, judges can
decide that civil trials are unnecessary if the people who sue 
have insufficient evidence. This is intended only for cases
where no reasonable jury would disagree. That's a difficult thing 
to determine, yet usage of summary judgement
has stretched to the point where some would argue it's being abused. For instance, judges grant fully,
or in part, over 70% of employers' requests to dismiss employment 
discrimination cases. In other cases, both the person who sues
and the person who defends forgo their right to go to court, instead resolving their dispute through
a professional arbitrator. These are generally lawyers, professors,
or former judges. Arbitration can be a smart decision
by both parties to avoid the requirements 
of a trial in court, but it's often agreed to unwittingly
when people sign contracts like employment applications
and consumer agreements. That can become a problem. For example, some arbitrators 
may be biased towards the companies
that give them cases. These are just some of the ways
in which juries have disappeared. But could the disappearance of juries
be a good thing? Well, juries aren't perfect. They're costly, time-consuming, and may make errors. And they're not always necessary, like when people can simply agree
to settle their disputes. But juries have their advantages. When properly selected, jurors are more representative of
the general population and don't have the same incentives
as prosecutors, legislators, or judges seeking reelection or promotion. The founders of the United States trusted
in the wisdom of impartial groups of citizens to check the power of all three branches
of government. And the jury trial itself has given
ordinary citizens a central role in upholding
the social fabric. So will the jury system in the U.S.
survive into the future?

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: A judge can prevent a case from going to a jury in a civil case by ordering __________.
Options: A. Summary judgment, B. Arbitration, C. Jail, D. Settlement
Correct Option: A

The Constitution no longer requires jury trials, C. The Supreme Court has permitted procedures like plea bargaining and summary judgement, D. Juries are too costly and time-consuming Correct Option: C

They are more representative of the general population and don't have the same incentives as prosecutors, legislators, or judges, C. They are only necessary in cases where people cannot agree to settle their disputes, D. They are perfect and never make errors Correct Option: B
Question 7: How has the proportion of guilty pleas changed in the United States between the 19th century and the 21st century? Options: A. It has decreased from 90% to 20%, B. It has increased from 20% to 90%, C. It has remained the same, D. It has only changed in civil cases Correct Option: B
Question 8: According to the transcript, what is the intended purpose of summary judgement? Options: A. To decide all civil cases, B. To determine the guilt of defendants, C. To resolve monetary disputes, D. To dismiss cases where no reasonable jury would disagree Correct Option: D
Question 9: What is a potential consequence of the decline of jury trials in the United States? Options: A. The power of the government will be unchecked, B. The social fabric will be upheld by other means, C. The number of errors in dispute resolution will decrease, D. The cost and time required for dispute resolution will decrease Correct Option: A

Ground Truth MCQ: A judge can prevent a case from going to a jury in a civil case by ordering __________.

Correct Option: A

Generated MCQ 8: According to the transcript, what is the intended purpose of summary judgement? 
Options: A. To decide all civil cases, B. To determine the guilt of defendants, C. To resolve monetary disputes, D. To dismiss cases where no reasonable jury would disagree
Correct Option: D

lead to hundreds of thousands of deaths every year, all because one in three people alive

can be signs of danger or disease, triggering our innate sense of disgust. This biological instinct ended up in the moral
codes of many religions, like this passage from the Old Testament instructing the Hebrews
to do their Exodus in aâ€¦ hole-y fashion. Roman society was comfortable with caca. At one point, Rome had 144 public toiletsâ€¦
long open benches that emptied into the Cloaca Maxima, a sewer system that carried waste
to the Tiber river. But the vast majority of Romans simply pooped
in a pot and threw it into the street. As waste and disease piled up, Romans pointed
to the stink as the cause of sickness. After the Roman Empire faded away, this connection
between bad air and bad health persisted, clogging up toilet innovation for more than
a thousand years. During medieval outbreaks like the Plague,
doctors wore pointed masks, filled with strong herbs or perfumes to â€œcleanseâ€ bad air,
which they believed to be the cause of disease. They were wrong, but this obsession with stink

with crap. With crap comes cholera, an infection from

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 9, Question 2

Options: A. excessive loss of blood, B. blood poisoning, C. vomiting, D. diarrhea and dehydration

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 10, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Approximately 7 million people around the 
world die from heart attacks every year, and cardiovascular disease, which causes heart attacks and other
problems like strokes, is the world's leading killer. So what causes a heart attack? Like all muscles, the heart needs oxygen, and during a heart attack,
it can't get enough. Fatty deposits, or plaques, develop on the walls 
of our coronary arteries. Those are the vessels that supply
oxygenated blood to the heart. These plaques grow as we age, sometimes getting chunky, hardened, or enflamed. Eventually, the plaques can turn
into blockages. If one of the plaques ruptures or cracks, a blood clot will form around it
in minutes, and a partially closed artery
can become completely blocked. Blood flow is cut off 
to the cardiac muscle and the oxygen-starved cells start to die
within several minutes. This is a myocardial infarction, or heart attack. Things can rapidly deteriorate
in the absence of treatment. The injured muscle may not be able
to pump blood as well, and its rhythm might be thrown off. In the worst case scenario,
a heart attack can cause sudden death. And how do you know that someone
is having a heart attack? The most common symptom is chest pain caused by the oxygen-deprived 
heart muscle. Patients describe it as crushing
or vice-like. It can radiate to the left arm, jaw, back, or abdomen. But it's not always as sudden and dramatic
as it is in the movies. Some people experience nausea or shortness of breath. Symptoms may be less prominent
in women and the elderly. For them, weakness and tiredness
may be the main signal. And surprisingly, in many people, especially those with diabetes,
which affects the nerves that carry pain, a heart attack may be silent. If you think that someone might be 
having a heart attack, the most important thing 
is to respond quickly. If you have access to emergency medical
services, call them. They're the fastest way 
to get to a hospital. Taking aspirin, which thins the blood, and nitroglycerin, 
which opens up the artery, can help keep the heart attack
from getting worse. In the emergency room, 
doctors can diagnose a heart attack. They commonly use an electrocardiogram to measure the heart's 
electrical activity and a blood test to assess 
heart muscle damage. The patient is then taken to a high-tech
cardiac suite where tests are done 
to locate the blockages. Cardiologists can reopen 
the blocked artery by inflating it with a balloon
in a procedure called an angioplasty. Frequently, they also insert a metal
or polymer stent that will hold the artery open. More extensive blockages might require
coronary artery bypass surgery. Using a piece of vein or artery
from another part of the body, heart surgeons can reroute blood flow
around the blockage. These procedures reestablish circulation
to the cardiac muscle, restoring heart function. Heart attack treatment is advancing, but prevention is vital. Genetics and lifestyle factors
both affect your risk. And the good news is that you can
change your lifestyle. Exercise, a healthy diet,
and weight loss all lower the risk of heart attacks, whether you've had one before or not. Doctors recommend exercising
a few times a week, doing both aerobic activity
and strength training. A heart-healthy diet is low
in sugar and saturated fats, which are both linked to heart disease. So what should you eat? Lots of fiber from vegetables, chicken and fish instead of red meat, whole grains and nuts like walnuts
and almonds all seem to be beneficial. A good diet and exercise plan can also
keep your weight in a healthy range, which will lower 
your heart attack risk as well. And of course, medications can also
help prevent heart attacks. Doctors often prescribe low-dose
aspirin, for example, particularly for patients who've
already had a heart attack and for those known to be
at high risk. And drugs that help manage risk factors, like high blood pressure, cholesterol,
and diabetes, will make heart attacks less likely, too. Heart attacks may be common, 
but they don't have to be inevitable. A healthy diet, avoiding tobacco use, staying fit, and enjoying plenty of sleep
and lots of laughter all go a long way in making sure
your body's most important muscle keeps on beating.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How many deaths occur annually around the world from cardiovascular disease?
Options: A. 500,000, B. 3 million, C. 7 million, D. 100 million
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the leading cause of death worldwide, responsible for approximately 7 million deaths every year? Options: A. Cancer, B. Cardiovascular disease, C. Diabetes, D. Stroke Correct Option: B
Question 2: What happens to the heart during a myocardial infarction (heart attack)? Options: A. The heart receives too much oxygen, causing it to beat faster., B. The heart is unable to get enough oxygen, causing cells to die., C. The heart becomes inflamed, causing it to pump more blood., D. The heart stops beating due to electrical activity issues. Correct Option: B
Question 3: If someone is experiencing symptoms of a heart attack, what is the most important thing to do first? Options: A. Give them aspirin and nitroglycerin., B. Call emergency medical services., C. Try to diagnose the issue yourself., D. Tell them to rest and see if it goes away. Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is the primary purpose of an electrocardiogram in diagnosing a heart attack? Options: A. To measure heart muscle damage, B. To assess the heart's electrical activity, C. To locate blockages in the coronary arteries, D. To check for high blood pressure Correct Option: B
Question 5: What is the goal of an angioplasty procedure in treating a heart attack? Options: A. To reroute blood flow around the blockage, B. To inflate the blocked artery with a balloon, C. To insert a stent to hold the artery open, D. Both B and C Correct Option: D
Question 6: Which symptom of a heart attack may be less prominent in women and the elderly? Options: A. Chest pain, B. Nausea, C. Shortness of breath, D. Weakness and tiredness Correct Option: D
Question 7: How does regular exercise, such as aerobic activity and strength training, affect the risk of heart attacks? Options: A. Increase the risk, B. Lower the risk, C. Have no impact on the risk, D. Only lower the risk for those who have had a heart attack before Correct Option: B
Question 8: What type of diet is recommended to lower the risk of heart attacks? Options: A. High in sugar and saturated fats, B. Low in fiber and high in red meat, C. Low in sugar and saturated fats, high in fiber and whole grains, D. Vegetarian or vegan only Correct Option: C
Question 9: What is the benefit of taking low-dose aspirin for patients who have had a heart attack or are at high risk? Options: A. It helps manage high blood pressure, B. It lowers cholesterol levels, C. It helps prevent future heart attacks, D. It has no impact on heart health Correct Option: C
Question 10: According to the transcript, which lifestyle factors can contribute to a lower risk of heart attacks? Options: A. Regular exercise, healthy diet, and tobacco use, B. Regular exercise, healthy diet, and plenty of sleep, C. Regular exercise, healthy diet, weight loss, and plenty of sleep, D. Regular exercise, healthy diet, weight loss, plenty of sleep, and lots of laughter Correct Option: D


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 1. 

Although the question phrasing is different, both the ground truth MCQ and Question 1 refer to the annual number of deaths caused by cardiovascular disease. The correct option in Question 1 (B. Cardiovascular disease) corresponds to the correct option in the ground truth MCQ (C. 7 million), as Question 1 states that cardiovascular disease is "responsible for approximately 7 million deaths every year."

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 1.

**Transcript**:
Approximately 7 million people around the 
world die from heart attacks every year, and cardiovascular disease, which causes heart attacks and other
problems like strokes, is the world's leading killer. So what causes a heart attack? Like all muscles, the heart needs oxygen, and during a heart attack,
it can't get enough. Fatty deposits, or plaques, develop on the walls 
of our coronary arteries. Those are the vessels that supply
oxygenated blood to the heart. These plaques grow as we age, sometimes getting chunky, hardened, or enflamed. Eventually, the plaques can turn
into blockages. If one of the plaques ruptures or cracks, a blood clot will form around it
in minutes, and a partially closed artery
can become completely blocked. Blood flow is cut off 
to the cardiac muscle and the oxygen-starved cells start to die
within several minutes. This is a myocardial infarction, or heart attack. Things can rapidly deteriorate
in the absence of treatment. The injured muscle may not be able
to pump blood as well, and its rhythm might be thrown off. In the worst case scenario,
a heart attack can cause sudden death. And how do you know that someone
is having a heart attack? The most common symptom is chest pain caused by the oxygen-deprived 
heart muscle. Patients describe it as crushing
or vice-like. It can radiate to the left arm, jaw, back, or abdomen. But it's not always as sudden and dramatic
as it is in the movies. Some people experience nausea or shortness of breath. Symptoms may be less prominent
in women and the elderly. For them, weakness and tiredness
may be the main signal. And surprisingly, in many people, especially those with diabetes,
which affects the nerves that carry pain, a heart attack may be silent. If you think that someone might be 
having a heart attack, the most important thing 
is to respond quickly. If you have access to emergency medical
services, call them. They're the fastest way 
to get to a hospital. Taking aspirin, which thins the blood, and nitroglycerin, 
which opens up the artery, can help keep the heart attack
from getting worse. In the emergency room, 
doctors can diagnose a heart attack. They commonly use an electrocardiogram to measure the heart's 
electrical activity and a blood test to assess 
heart muscle damage. The patient is then taken to a high-tech
cardiac suite where tests are done 
to locate the blockages. Cardiologists can reopen 
the blocked artery by inflating it with a balloon
in a procedure called an angioplasty. Frequently, they also insert a metal
or polymer stent that will hold the artery open. More extensive blockages might require
coronary artery bypass surgery. Using a piece of vein or artery
from another part of the body, heart surgeons can reroute blood flow
around the blockage. These procedures reestablish circulation
to the cardiac muscle, restoring heart function. Heart attack treatment is advancing, but prevention is vital. Genetics and lifestyle factors
both affect your risk. And the good news is that you can
change your lifestyle. Exercise, a healthy diet,
and weight loss all lower the risk of heart attacks, whether you've had one before or not. Doctors recommend exercising
a few times a week, doing both aerobic activity
and strength training. A heart-healthy diet is low
in sugar and saturated fats, which are both linked to heart disease. So what should you eat? Lots of fiber from vegetables, chicken and fish instead of red meat, whole grains and nuts like walnuts
and almonds all seem to be beneficial. A good diet and exercise plan can also
keep your weight in a healthy range, which will lower 
your heart attack risk as well. And of course, medications can also
help prevent heart attacks. Doctors often prescribe low-dose
aspirin, for example, particularly for patients who've
already had a heart attack and for those known to be
at high risk. And drugs that help manage risk factors, like high blood pressure, cholesterol,
and diabetes, will make heart attacks less likely, too. Heart attacks may be common, 
but they don't have to be inevitable. A healthy diet, avoiding tobacco use, staying fit, and enjoying plenty of sleep
and lots of laughter all go a long way in making sure
your body's most important muscle keeps on beating.
